posts.name: Reed Papakonstantinou
posts.cooked:
Hello, I am new to java and FRC programming, and that is true for the rest of my team’s programmers. We are having trouble operating a double solenoid. We are trying to have a joystick button extend or retract a pneumatics cylinder. The Solenoid works when manually extended (the red buttons on the solenoid) but our program doesn’t work. I have included our code below. Thanks for any help you can provide. In Robot.java

Our Pneumatics subsystem, Pneumatics.java

Then our two instant commands Pneumatics1 and Pneumatics 2

and then robotcontainer

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked:
Can you clarify what you mean when you say “doesn’t work”? Does it do the wrong thing or nothing at all?

I’ll let someone else look through your code, but here’s the general troubleshooting process I would follow.

Confirm electrical is correct (12V/24V solenoid? What mode is the PCM/PH in? Solenoid is wired to correct PCM/PH port numbers?)

Confirm device configuration is correct (PCM/PH CAN ID shown in Phoenix Tuner/REV Hardware Client matches what’s in code?)

Confirm minimal project is able to control PCM/PH ports correctly (create new TimedRobot project and only add Solenoid object then deploy. Does compressor turn on?  Try adding line to project to command solenoid. Does it do as expected?)

posts.name: Reed Papakonstantinou
posts.cooked: By doesn’t work I mean that when the joystick button is pressed the Solenoid doesn’t deploy and retract. I have robotics later today and I will follow the troubleshooting advice you gave then. Thank you very much.

posts.name: NewtonCrosby
posts.cooked:
A couple of things:

Why do you instantiate your subsystem outside the RobotContainer?  Makes things a lot weirder to follow when looking at your code.

Unless you really need to control the compressor in your own custom closed-loop way, you don’t need a Compressor object in your system. The Javadocs for Compressor explain this . You just need to instantiate your DoubleSolenoid in your subsystem, and the compressor will work in closed-loop mode automatically.

Do the solenoids you’re using have any visual cue as to which side they are being set to?  The ones we’ve used over the years illuminate an LED on the actual device showing which side is being driven.

Have you visualized what the subsystem value is for the DoubleSolenoid while the code is running?  You can add a SmartDashboard or Shuffleboard entry that puts the current return value of pitchSolenoid.get() in your subsystem periodic method to see what’s happening.

Have you been observing the Scheduler widget in Shuffleboard to make sure that your commands are getting scheduled and run as you think they should be?

posts.name: Patrick Freivald
posts.cooked:
The most common error with this result is electrical, not programming.

The PCM can do either 12V or 24V solenoids, and if you’re trying to run 24V solenoids with the PCM set to 12V, the lights will change but nothing else will happen. If you find that this is the case, fixing it is very, very easy–switch the VSOL jumper on the PCM from 12V to 24V.

posts.name: Reed Papakonstantinou
posts.cooked: We know the solenoid works and can actuate it from the smartdashboard. Our Solenoid doesn’t have those LEDs. We believe the problem is in the code. If someone could provide us a simple example of a command based pneumatics program that would be amazing. We have talked to other teams in our area and they are suffering similar issues. Thank you a ton for any help.

posts.cooked:
